item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to the guide about learning! This introduction will be short. (I don’t like wasting time with pointless lengthy introductions.

item.title: Redefining learning
item.description: As always, I start my guides by making sure we’re all on the same page. What is learning? What is our concrete goal?

item.title: Learning styles (don't exist)
item.description: We can be short about this. There is no evidence that personal learning styles exist. There is, however, evidence that it helps to present information in all possible ways.

item.title: The four principles
item.description: If you remember one thing from this guide, make it these four principles. No, wait, if you implement one thing from this guide into your daily life, make it these four principles.

item.title: The Do principle
item.description: In theory, this principle is easy. Just do something. Want to become a writer? Start writing. Want to be a musician?

item.title: The Time principle
item.description: The time principle is simple and just requires … time. It doesn’t work if you train something without downtime.

item.title: The Feedback principle
item.description: The feedback principle is about critical analysis. Both self-analysis and putting yourself in situations where feedback comes from the outside.

item.title: The Experiment principle
item.description: Ah, this is the fun one! The other principles might have seem tough. They require some discipline, some training, some other skills.

item.title: Spaced versus Focused
item.description: We’ve discussed the four principles and how to apply them. This is, essentially, all that you need. Just that constant loop of doing something a lot, reflecting on it, and experimenting.

item.title: Varied versus Predictable
item.description: A related topic to focused learning is predictable learning. You know exactly what you’ll be looking at, because you focus on that thing.

item.title: Mind versus Body
item.description: This course has mostly focused on your mind. That isn’t strange, it’s a guide on learning and brain power.

item.title: Intrinsic versus Extrinsic
item.description: This chapter is about intrinsic motivation versus extrinsic motivation. This guide has told you all sorts of things you can do to learn effectively—but you still need to do them.

item.title: Self-Study versus No-Study
item.description: As if this guide isn’t controversial enough, I am going to tell you to “no study”. Why? Whenever I talk about this topic with anyone, they always say something like: “but you just like self-study!

item.title: Deep versus Superficial
item.description: So far, I’ve basically told you to just do something. Do, and do, and do, and you will get a great understanding of any skill.

item.title: Environment & Mindset
item.description: We’re nearing the end of this guide. I’ve told you everything you need to know. You have the tools to supercharge learning anything.

item.title: Desirable Difficulty
item.description: While reading this guide, you might have thought—numerous times—that it’s all very tough and a lot of work. I’m not here to tell you otherwise.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve finished the guide on learning anything. I sincerely hope this helps you realize your full potential. To gain a deep understanding of any skill or topic, and do it while having fun and not wasting time.
